p: Vector control remains an important means for the prevention and control of vector-borne epidemics by reducing the density of vector insects [ 10, 11]. Control of Aedes vectors currently relies on application of insecticides and habitat management [ 12]. However, continuous and intensive use of insecticides in the fields or in domestic setting has artificially created a direct or indirect selection pressure on vector insects, leading to the development of insecticide resistance (IR) [ 1, 12].
